Explore Our Events

Join us at Inspire '25, the ultimate tech fest where innovation meets inspiration. This year, we're bringing together industry leaders, tech enthusiasts, and passionate creators to explore cutting-edge technologies, groundbreaking ideas, and future trends.

Seeds to System

Relay Coding is a programming event that primarily focuses on coding skills and the ability to understand and continue code between two participants.

Register Now

Techno Theatre

Fusion of Dance, Drama, and Technology. Participants are required to unleash their tech-savvy minds through dance and drama.
CATEGORIES: Dance, Drama.

Register Now

Game Storm

LAN Gaming: Group Event - Counter-Strike (4 members per team), Group Event - BGMI (4 members per team), Single Event - NFS.

Register Now

Shark Tank

Shark Tank is a tech-based pitching event where students present innovative product or service models, focusing on feasibility, market potential, revenue, costs, and funding. Judges assess creativity, viability, and strategy.

Register Now

Legacy Quest

E-Treasure Hunt is an exciting, technology-driven adventure where teams compete to solve a series of digital and logical challenges. The event is designed to test participants' problem-solving skills, technical knowledge, and teamwork.

Register Now

C-VOLUTION

C-Volution is a C programming challenge featuring 30 MCQs that test fundamental concepts. Participants have 20 minutes to complete the quiz, with no penalty for unattempted questions. The top 50% advance to the next round, and those who submit within the first 5 minutes earn a +2 speed bonus.

Register Now

Rays of Hope

Rays of hope is to navigate the lasers like a beam of light while being surrounded by a web of laser beams.

Register Now

Dan Dhana Dan

Join us for the ultimate multi-round showdown where you and your team will tackle mental and physical challenges, navigate blindfolded mazes, and race against time! Only the fastest, sharpest, and most synchronized teams will make it to the final treasure hunt. Do you have what it takes to claim victory and prove your dominance? Gather your squad and step up to the challenge in this adrenaline packed adventure!

Register Now

Wallstreet Wizards

Step into the role of an elite trading team and experience the thrill of the stock market! Manage your portfolio, respond to market news, and trade stocks in real time to build the most valuable portfolio. The team with the highest overall score wins!

The Evolution of Computers

1st Generation (1940-1956) - Vacuum Tubes

Technology Used: Vacuum tubes for circuitry, magnetic drums for memory Characteristics: Large, expensive, consumed a lot of power, generated heat Programming Language: Machine language (binary) Examples: ENIAC, UNIVAC-I Usage: Scientific calculations, military applications

2nd Generation (1956-1963) - Transistors

Technology Used: Transistors replaced vacuum tubes Characteristics: Smaller, faster, more reliable, energy-efficient Programming Language: Assembly language, early high-level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN) Examples: IBM 1401, UNIVAC 1108 Usage: Business applications, scientific computing

3rd Generation (1964-1971) - Integrated Circuits (ICs)

Technology Used: Integrated Circuits (ICs) replaced transistors Characteristics: Smaller size, better processing speed, lower cost Programming Language: High-level languages like C and BASIC Examples: IBM 360 series, PDP-8

4th Generation (1971-Present) - Microprocessors

Technology Used: Microprocessors (thousands of ICs on a single chip) Characteristics: Personal computers (PCs) became common, graphical user interfaces (GUIs) Programming Language: C, C++, Java, Python Examples: Intel 4004, IBM PC, Apple Macintosh Usage: Office applications, entertainment, internet

5th Generation (Present & Beyond) - Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Quantum Computing

Technology Used: AI, machine learning, quantum computing, nanotechnology Characteristics: Self-learning systems, advanced parallel processing, cloud computing Programming Language: Python, R, AI-based languages like Prolog, Lisp Examples: IBM Watson, Google's Quantum Computer Usage: AI-based decision-making, robotics, cloud computing, voice recognition

6th Generation (Future & Beyond) - AI, Quantum & Beyond

Technology Used: Quantum computing, artificial intelligence (AGI), nanotechnology, optical computing Characteristics: Self-learning AI, ultra-fast quantum processing, human-brain-like computing, energy-efficient systems Programming Language: Python, R, Q# (Quantum), Prolog, Lisp Examples: Google's Quantum Supremacy, IBM's Q System One, AI-driven robotics Usage: AI-powered automation, fully autonomous robots, real-time global decision-making, medical advancements, space exploration
